resources.title: Christmas, Bulgaria, 1980s
resources.notes: The local Bulgarian men implement the custom of Koleduvane on Christmas. They enter every house and sing songs for health and material wealth.
resources.copyright: Access is for research purposes only

resources.title: The Queen's Christmas Tree, 1857
resources.notes: From an album of photographs collected and arranged by Prince Albert. A photograph of a Christmas tree and a display of gifts in a room at Windsor Castle. Victoria and Albert helped to popularise the German custom of decorating fir trees at Christmas time, which had originally been introduced into England by Queen Charlotte. Gifts were exchanged on Christmas Eve: the photograph shows several artworks exchanged between the royal couple in 1857.
resources.copyright: Royal Collection Trust and Royal Archives / © Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II 2019-2022

resources.title: Mosaic of Jesus and his ancestors
resources.notes: The Genealogy of Christ is a fourteenth-century mosaic that decorates the southern dome of Chora Church, now the Kariye Museum, Istanbul.
resources.copyright: Church, Chloe. 2021. 'The Descendants of Christ Pantocrator', in The Visual Commentary Of Scripture ed. by Ben Quash. (London: The Visual Commentary on Scripture Foundation).

resources.title: Figures Dancing Around a Fire
resources.notes: The local Bulgarian men implement the custom of Koleduvane on Christmas. They enter every house and sing songs for health and material wealth.

resources.title: Maria (The Return)
resources.notes: The sculpture, commissioned by Uppsala Cathedral in 2003 and installed in 2005, answered their brief for a ‘visible reinstatement of the Virgin Mary inside the church’ after the upheavals of the Reformation.
resources.copyright: Gannon, Anna. 2021. 'Welcome Back', in The Visual Commentary Of Scripture ed. by Ben Quash. (London: The Visual Commentary on Scripture Foundation).

resources.title: Miss Kate Terry as a boy
resources.notes: Given to Queen Victoria by Prince Albert as a Christmas gift. A photograph of a group of actors appearing as members of the crowd during the 'Historical Episode' inserted between acts in Richard II at the Princess’s Theatre in 1857. Kate Terry is second from the right as a young boy, grouped with another actress playing a young woman and three smaller children. The wide variety of objects in the Royal Collection and Royal Archives which relate to this production of Richard II invite reflection on how the Victorian royal family preferred to encounter their own history, as well as demonstrating their efforts to document family theatregoing.
resources.copyright: Royal Collection Trust and Royal Archives / © Her Majesty Queen Elizabeth II 2019-2022

resources.title: Christmas Card: Angel
resources.notes: The Genealogy of Christ is a fourteenth-century mosaic that decorates the southern dome of Chora Church, now the Kariye Museum, Istanbul.
resources.copyright: Collection UCLA Grunwald Center for the Graphic Arts, Hammer Museum

resources.title: The Lost Path
resources.notes: A woman clutching a baby is lost in the wilderness. Head bowed against the wind, she drags herself along a snow-laden path, protecting herself and her baby against the cold. The canvas is almost entirely white, representing heavy snowfall and enhancing the sense of disorientation. There is an absence of familiar reference points, either for the viewer or the subject of the painting—all seems lost.
resources.copyright: Domoney-Lyttle, Zanne. 2022. 'Fallen/Falling', in The Visual Commentary Of Scripture ed. by Ben Quash. (London: The Visual Commentary on Scripture Foundation).

resources.title: Beaver ornament
resources.notes: Felt stuffed beaver Christmas ornament with green holly.
resources.copyright: Gift of Ms. Anne Wertsner Wood. Some restrictions on use. Please contact MIT Museum for details.

resources.title: Untitled #5
resources.notes: A major figure in the Los Angeles art world, Lari Pittman produces large-scale, graphic paintings whose surfaces are populated with colorful, clashing imagery. Pittman worked as an interior designer for a decade before turning to painting full-time, and his work conveys a fascination with decoration and artifice. “A reflective, sensational surface is still a conduit for meaning,” he has said.
resources.copyright: Hammer Museum, Los Angeles. Purchase

resources.title: Christmas stocking
resources.notes: Christmas stocking with stocking stuffers (box of dominos, balsa wood glider shaped like Mrs. Santa Claus, magic trick, 2 bouncy balls, 1 hot wheel, one wood yoyo, one finger trap, a kazoo, a Santa Claus Pez dispenser, and a dreidel with chocolate coins). The stocking has the Boffo logo on it.
resources.copyright: Gift of Michael Dornbrook. No known copyright restrictions.

resources.title: Miss Tait and Tommy and the Carol Singers
resources.notes: 'Miss Tait and Tommy and the Carol Singers’ was originally published in Christmas Stories in 1985. Peering through Miss Tait’s window (illustrated here by John Lawrence), the children are astounded to see that 'Tommy the outcast' has brought driftwood for her fire and is contentedly eating an apple in her armchair. Miss Tait sees the children and invites them inside to eat and to receive a gift of a pound coin. In many of Brown’s tales and poems, outcasts and eccentrics like Tommy have a deeper spiritual understanding of the world around them and, in this case, of the true meaning of Christmas. This tale is unusual, though, for its topical references. Miss Tait has been without coal since the outbreak of the 1984 Miners’ Strike. The 'shiny pound coin' was first introduced in 1983. Often criticized for resisting progress and yearning for the past, Brown shows himself to be alive to contemporary developments.
resources.copyright: This exhibition was curated by Paul Barnaby, with assistance from Elizabeth Lawrence and Bianca Packham. Credit / Usage information for image: By permission of John Lawrence and the Perpetua Press

resources.title: Winter scene
resources.notes: A view of the Kleine Haarlemmersluis in win­ter with the Marte­laars­gracht beyond, seen from the Nieuwezijds Voor­burgwal
resources.copyright: Peck Collection, Ackland Art Museum, 12/08/2021

resources.title: The Adoration of the Magi
resources.notes: The subject of the Adoration of the Magi, along with the Adoration of the Shepherds, occupies pride of place in Jacopo Bassano's repertory. Jacopo and his family workshop produced several versions showing the three gift-bearing kings—traditionally representing three ages and three parts of the known world, including Africa—paying homage to the newborn Jesus as preeminent king.
resources.copyright: Mrs. Hedy Maria Allen [d. 1990], New York; bequeathed to Kimbell Art Foundation, Fort Worth, 1990.

resources.title: Teiglach Recipe
resources.notes: I plotzed when I looked at the back cover of the Fall 2017 Pakn Treger and saw the illustration accompanying Sima Beeri’s lovely piece about teiglach. I never commented on the matzah that my local grocery store used to display every year alongside Chanukah candles and gelt, but I feel compelled to kvetch now to inform your readers that the teiglach that I love looks nothing like sufganiyot. Teiglach was my grandmother’s crowning dish, a delicacy that she made once a year for a sweet Rosh Hashanah. Even in the 1950s, few of her friends even attempted it, and the version offered up in bakeries was a soggy imitation of her gooey, candy-like confection.
resources.copyright: Excerpt from a letter by Cynthia Francis Gensheimer sent to Pakn Treger and published on the website of the Yiddish Book Center.

resources.title: Prairie Winter
resources.notes: Abstract oil painting of a prairie winter scene and a train, grain silos, and smoke rising against a gray sky
resources.copyright: Clyfford Still Museum, Denver, CO. © City and County of Denver / ARS, NY.

resources.title: Snow Hill
resources.notes: Six figures holding brightly coloured ribbons dance around a maypole incongruously jutting out of a snowy hilltop, overlooking train tracks, a fence, and some scattered rural buildings. A seventh ribbon floats untended. Atop the pole stands an evergreen tree, somehow both apart from and a part of what happens below.
resources.copyright: Torretta, Zane. 2020. 'A Remembered Present', in The Visual Commentary Of Scripture ed. by Ben Quash. (London: The Visual Commentary on Scripture Foundation).

resources.title: Christmas at Moose Factory
resources.notes: Still from Native American short film directed by Alanis Obomsawin and produced by Wolf Koenig. Crayon drawings come to life at Christmas.
resources.copyright: Photo taken from the production, National Film Board of Canada. All rights reserved.

resources.title: Instrumentation Laboratory Christmas party
resources.notes: Black and white photo of party attendees lined to serve themselves at a long buffet table set with plates, food, candles and decorative arrangements.
resources.copyright: Some restrictions on use. Please contact MIT Museum for details.

resources.title: Machine Hallucinations: Nature Dreams
resources.notes: Machine Hallucinations: Nature Dreams is a long-term research project by Refik Anadol (b. 1985, Istanbul, Turkey) at the intersections of architecture, Artificial Intelligence-based digital art, and environmental aesthetics. The artwork is an AI data sculpture that draws upon a dataset of more than 300 million publicly available nature-related images of flowers, trees, mushrooms, landscapes, and clouds. This vast dataset is processed through a custom software developed by Anadol’s studio. A multisensory architectural exhibition of synesthetic reality experiments based on algorithms, Machine Hallucinations: Nature Dreams commemorates the inherent beauty of the planet Earth.
resources.copyright: Still. Courtesy Refik Anadol Studio

resources.title: Ice Scene with Two Men Push­ing a Sled
resources.notes: Dur­ing the sev­en­teenth cen­tu­ry in the Nether­lands, frigid tem­per­a­tures often endured for months, freez­ing canals, rivers, and water­ways that were, prag­mat­i­cal­ly, used by the Dutch peo­ple for both trans­porta­tion and recre­ation. Artists were espe­cial­ly inspired by their icy sur­round­ings, among them Ger­ard ter Borch, who com­plet­ed sev­er­al draw­ings of win­ter­time activ­i­ties around the age of six­teen. Here, two men push a woman in a sled with­out the aid of skates past cur­so­ri­ly drawn build­ings that per­haps rep­re­sent the city of Zwolle.
resources.copyright: Peck Collection, Ackland Art Museum, 11/08/2021

resources.title: The Three Kings
resources.notes: Image by David McClure (1926-1998), which places the Magi against a backdrop of both ancient violence (the Massacre of the Innocents) and contemporary, mediatized warfare. According to the artist’s son, Robin McClure, former Director of Painting at The Scottish Gallery, ‘the linking of religious content to current strife and bloodshed was very much part of [McClure’s] publicly viewable work at the time’. Beginning with 'a series of enigmatic religiously-themed works' in the early 1960s, his paintings became more 'biting, gruesome and specific in their references', largely due to the ‘much publicized and often graphic’ media images of the First Mafia War, which broke out in 1962 in Sicily, where McClure had earlier lived and worked. We should like to thank Robin McClure for permission to exhibit his father’s design and for commenting on his father’s work.
resources.copyright: Credit / Usage information: By permission of the Estate of David McClure

resources.title: Couple sitting by Christmas Tree at a party
resources.notes: The economic basis for professional black and white photography in Cameroon disappeared in 1998 with the introduction of new identity cards. They were issued with instant photographs, removing the need for 'passport photographs'. A small supporting industry of photographers, such as have been celebrated in exhibitions e.g. of the work of Seidou Keita, has effectively been destroyed. One such studio photographer is Jacques Toussele, with a collection of some 20,000 negatives, but who is aging and is not in the best of health. He can recognise many of the people in the photographs, enabling future research to be undertaken, thus greatly enhancing the importance of the archive. African black and white photography has been recognised as important through some celebrated exhibitions and publications (e.g. of Sidibé, Augustt and Keita) but this has not translated into action to preserve the work of other photographers. The aim of the project was to help protect the personal photographic archives of Mr J Toussele, a Cameroonian photographer in the town of Mbouda, Western Region, Cameroon. The archives represent a record of life in this area over the past thirty years.
resources.copyright: Jacques Touselle Photographs: box 123 [c 1975-1976], British Library, EAP054/1/116, https://eap.bl.uk/archive-file/EAP054-1-116

resources.title: The Madonna and Child
resources.notes: Hailed as the new Raphael, Parmigianino was one of the most influential artists of the sixteenth century, cultivating a mannered gracefulness of pose and physiognomy, combined with new and dramatic coloristic effects, that transformed the classicism of his Renaissance predecessors. Here, he draws upon the work of Leonardo, Raphael, and Michelangelo in counterposing the serenely pensive Virgin with her active Son, who tugs at his mother’s veil. But the compressed pose of the Christ Child and the tall, sweeping foreheads of mother and child introduce elements of Parmigianino’s distinctive Mannerism. The Virgin’s exquisite beauty is an outward sign of her inner grace, which Parmigianino reinforces through the golden strands of her ribboned hair and the fluid rhythms of her gossamer drapery.
resources.copyright: purchased through (Simon Dickinson Ltd., London) by Kimbell Art Foundation, Fort Worth, 1995
